item.title: Fable Is Abandoning One Of The RPG Series‚Äô Defining Mechanics And Fans Aren‚Äôt Happy
item.content:encoded:
During yesterday‚Äôs Xbox Developer Direct, we got the most expansive look at the Fable reboot we‚Äôve seen yet. Playground Games is picking up the series after original developer Lionhead Studios shut down in 2016, and it definitely feels like the studio is modernizing the action RPG series with an open world and a new morality system. With that new morality system, Fable is changing what was one of the core pillars of the series: your appearance will no longer be determined by whether or not you‚Äôre making good or evil decisions. In fact, it‚Äôs abandoning the idea that any of your actions are objectively good or evil altogether.

For those that didn‚Äôt play any of Lionhead‚Äôs Fable games, like many games of the early 2000s they have a binary ‚Äúhero or villain‚Äù morality system where doing things like helping people in need would move you toward the ‚Äúgood‚Äù side of the spectrum while doing things like skinning people alive in front of their weeping mother would move you toward the ‚Äúevil‚Äù side.

In the Fable games, the decisions you made would gradually alter your character‚Äôs look, with good characters appearing pristine and almost angelic, and evil players growing horns and turning into a monster. I tended to play evil characters in these games and wasn‚Äôt thrilled that my characters were turning into uggos, but that‚Äôs the contract you sign when you play these games. Playground Games‚Äô Fable, however, is approaching morality differently, and so this mechanic is going out the window.

As illustrated in the showcase, Fable is trying to handle morality in a more ‚Äúsubjective‚Äù way, which essentially means the game won‚Äôt treat your actions as simply ‚Äúgood‚Äù or ‚Äúevil,‚Äù but rather that NPCs will react to the things you do based on their own proclivities. So you can kick people out of their homes as their landlord, and some rich idiot who lives for that shit might still think you‚Äôre a standup guy. Since things aren‚Äôt so black and white this time around, Playground‚Äôs Ralph Fulton tells IGN it‚Äôs abandoning the morality-based appearance-changing system of previous games because there is no ‚Äúobjective‚Äù morality system to attach them to.

That sort of character morphing feature, obviously a really central part of the original games. It‚Äôs not in ours. And I‚Äôll tell you why. There‚Äôs probably a couple of reasons. One, I guess it‚Äôs about that high level principle I was talking about, that there is no objective good and evil. And the original games were predicated on there being an objective good and an objective evil, and you were somewhere along that scale, and that‚Äôs what determined how your appearance changed.

But for us, that doesn‚Äôt really work. The way I‚Äôve described our morality system working, you‚Äôre never that thing, absolutely. You‚Äôre different things to different people based on what they like or what they choose to value. So, that‚Äôs one reason that it didn‚Äôt work.

There‚Äôs another reason, which is in our game, you build reputation based on the settlement, the town, the city that you‚Äôre in, the part of the world that you‚Äôre in. But when you go to a new place, a place you‚Äôve never been to before, you walk in without any reputation and thus nobody knows what to think about you. And you can almost, through your behavior, through your choices, form completely different reputations, a completely different identity, if you like, in that place from the place that you were last time. And you can do that across all the locations in the game.

Now, you couldn‚Äôt do that if you walked in with horns and a trident. Your reputation would precede you in that instance. And honestly, that ability to be completely in control of your identity and thus what people think of you felt more important to us than that legacy feature. So, it worked great in those games. It didn‚Äôt seem to fit in ours, so we don‚Äôt have it.

From a roleplaying perspective, I get why this decision was made, and I‚Äôll be glad that my future bald, bearded gay won‚Äôt have to look like a demon while I‚Äôm trying to woo the men of Albion. But it is leaving behind what was a core pillar of the Fable series back in the day, and long-time fans who have been waiting over a decade for a new Fable are reacting accordingly.

they've confirmed in an IGN interview that your actions will not transform your appearance. üò† That's a core part of why I love Fable and I'll miss that.

Everything else looks fantastic, though. Smart evolutions, faithful vibe, incredible environments. I'm happy to be excited. https://t.co/aqiDTHLR2o

‚Äî Jake Baldino (@JakeBaldino) January 22, 2026

wait what?? that's like Fable's whole deal! https://t.co/E9mzl8OvZO

‚Äî Paul Tassi (@PaulTassi) January 22, 2026

‚ÄúNPC‚Äôs and how your character looked reflecting your actions was pretty important for me,‚Äù Disastrous_Fig5609 wrote on Reddit. ‚ÄúYou watch the character grow up from childhood, then you watch them grow into a hero or a villain. You might not be able to plant an acorn and watch it grow into a tree as you play the game, but that element of shaping the world around you with your actions still somewhat persisted with shaping your character with your actions.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe location based reputation is cool, but it absolutely could have just been a dual system,‚Äù  ForestBrah01209 wrote in the same thread. ‚ÄúOne town will see you one way, another town will see you a different way. However, if I‚Äôm absolutely evil and move to another town, I‚Äôm still absolutely evil, even if my new neighbors think I‚Äôm just another stranger or even a nice guy. Shame that I won‚Äôt be able to rock the devil horns anymore.‚Äù

Fable is the first game in the series to have a character creator, so at least it‚Äôs not like everyone‚Äôs characters are going to look the same. We‚Äôll see if there are enough character customization options to let players at least manually emulate some of those old Fable transformations when the game launches in the fall.

item.title: Bose Goes on ANC Headphone Clearance, New QuietComfort Ultra Earbuds (2nd Gen) Crash to an All-Time Low
item.content:encoded:
The Bose New QuietComfort Ultra Earbuds feature an Active Noise Control system and an immersive audio system, and they fit well for extended periods. They also include soft ear tips that seal against the ear to eliminate ambient noise, but do not feel too tight. These earbuds feature Bluetooth compatibility for phones, tablets, laptops, and other devices. Additionally, the earbuds have a white smoke finish, have touch controls, and a compact charging case that is small enough to carry in a pocket. They were made to be portable while keeping the audio front and center.

You can find the Bose New QuietComfort Ultra Earbuds for $249 at Amazon. This is a $50 discount from their normal price of $299. So this represents a 17% discount.

See at Amazon

Earbuds with the style, comfort, and quality of Bose headphones

The noise-cancellation on the Bose New QuietComfort Ultra Earbuds works to cancel out engine noise, conversations, and other background noise. If you would rather hear some outside noise, then the Aware Mode provides an alternative. It allows you to hear what is happening outside and smooths out sudden spikes in decibel levels caused by loud noises, such as clanging dishes and slamming doors. In addition to providing awareness of your surroundings, if you prefer more isolation, Quiet Mode reduces ambient noise so you can enjoy your playlists, calls, podcasts, etc., at a lower volume.

CustomTune technology in the Bose New QuietComfort Ultra Earbuds determines how sound behaves in your ears and adjusts noise cancellation and equalization accordingly. The earbuds produce a test tone when you insert them and measure the response. Then it sets the bass, midrange, and treble to match your ear shape. Bose Immersive Audio provides a spatial effect that creates the illusion that music and video are coming from in front of you rather than inside your head.

The fit and comfort of the earbuds are due to the combination of the soft silicone eartips and the flexible stability bands. There are multiple sizes of each component, and they can be combined in 9 ways. The umbrella-shaped tips provide additional blockage of ambient noise. Plus, they are rated IPX4, so they are suitable for use during sweating or light rain.

The call quality of the Bose New QuietComfort Ultra Earbuds depends on the noise-rejecting microphones and processing specifically tailored to ensure your voice is heard clearly. The microphones are focused on capturing your voice while rejecting wind and background noise; therefore, the caller hears you, not the surrounding noise.

As mentioned earlier, battery life and charging capabilities are configured to provide you with enough time to listen to whatever content you desire. Battery life is approximately 6 hours in Quiet, Aware, or Immersive Modes, and about 4 hours in Immersive Mode. The case supports 3 charging cycles and can be charged via a USB-C port or a wireless charging pad. These are great headphones, and you‚Äôll want to take advantage of the $249 sale price instead of the regular list price of $299 now.

item.title: Govee LED Floor Lamp Drops Again to a New Record Low After Another Surprise Price Cut on Amazon
item.content:encoded:
A new year often brings the urge to refresh your surroundings, and home upgrades don‚Äôt have to involve expensive furniture or major renovations. Small changes can dramatically shift how a space feels, and lighting sits at the top of that list. The right light can make a room feel warmer, calmer, and far more inviting. That‚Äôs exactly where the Govee LED floor lamp comes in, especially now that it‚Äôs available at a steep discount. Normally priced at $100, this modern lamp is currently 35% off, dropping the price to just $65 for a limited time.

The Govee floor lamp takes a sleek, minimalist approach. Its design features a single vertical light bar that tucks neatly into the corner of a room, projecting light outward across the walls. This indirect lighting instantly softens the space and eliminates harsh glare. Thanks to its RGB LED technology, the lamp can glow in virtually any color you can imagine, allowing you to adjust the mood of your room in seconds.

See at Amazon

Many people have grown tired of harsh overhead lighting‚Äîmyself included. We have a strict, ‚ÄúNo Big Light,‚Äù policy in my home. Ceiling fixtures and rows of recessed lights can make living spaces feel sterile and overly bright. Lighting placed closer to eye level or below creates a more relaxed environment, perfect for unwinding at the end of the day. The Govee floor lamp excels at this, delivering ambient light that feels intentional and cozy rather than clinical.

Set the Mood, Any Mood

Customization with this lamp is near limitless. It supports multi-color displays and offers 85 built-in scene modes to match different moods and occasions. Warm oranges and yellows work well for quiet evenings with a book or movie, while vibrant color combinations can energize a room for social gatherings. Holiday decorating becomes effortless with themed color options, and music sync mode adds another layer of fun by matching light patterns to the beat of your favorite songs.

The Govee floor lamp works with Alexa and Google Assistant, allowing you to control brightness, colors, and power with simple voice commands. Scheduling and automation options let you create routines that fit your lifestyle. Lights can turn on as the sun sets, dim automatically late at night, or shift scenes for special events without manual input.

Setup is refreshingly easy. After assembling the vertical bar, you simply run the light strip through it, plug it in, and you‚Äôre ready to go. No complicated tools or technical experience are required.

This one lamp can completely change how a room feels, and at just $65, it‚Äôs a no brainer. Give your home the cozy refresh that it needs for 2026.

item.title: The Third Final Fantasy VII Remake Game Is Playable And Has An Even Better Version Of Queen‚Äôs Blood
item.content:encoded:
Final Fantasy VII Rebirth is known for its minigame glut, but it did have at least a few bangers in the mix. One of those was Queen‚Äôs Blood, a card game that you could play with various citizens throughout the world, and it even had its own extensive side story to follow. This was new for Rebirth‚Äìapparently Queen‚Äôs Blood hadn‚Äôt yet caught on in Midgar, where Remake takes place‚Äìand it sounds like Square Enix wants to expand upon it in the upcoming third game.

In an interview with Polygon, director Naoki Hamaguchi confirmed Queen‚Äôs Blood will make a return in the as-of-yet-untitled third game, but it will be a little bit different.

‚ÄúQueen‚Äôs Blood is a very popular and beloved minigame, and I believe a lot of people are still wanting something like that,‚Äù Hamaguchi told Polygon. ‚ÄúI want to expand on Queen‚Äôs Blood so we are enhancing it, and giving you a more powered-up version of it when you see that third installment‚Ä¶ Queen‚Äôs Blood is still going to be available in the third installment. We just want to expand on it.‚Äù

What could those enhancements entail? New cards, mechanics, or maybe the board will just be twice as big, allowing for more territory-claiming plays? We probably won‚Äôt find out for a while, but Queen‚Äôs Blood isn‚Äôt the only minigame in the third entry, as it will also signal the return of the original Final Fantasy VII‚Äôs snowboarding segment, which Hamaguchi says will be more than ‚Äújust a simple snowboarding minigame.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm afraid I can‚Äôt delve too much into the details, but we understand that it‚Äôs not going to be just a simple snowboarding minigame. We want to make sure that it‚Äôs incorporated into the story to have that sort of connection with the theming of it,‚Äù he said.

The third Final Fantasy VII remake is probably still a ways away, but it does seem like the game is coming along and is in a playable state.

‚ÄúIn terms of the third installment, I believe we are coming along very smoothly,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe have set a schedule for ourselves, and I believe we are tracking on time for the milestones we have set. So I‚Äôm really thankful for the development team and I have so much respect for them working on this project. I believe that at this point the game is playable, technically, but we are still trying to polish it so it is at a quality where we can deliver it to our players.‚Äù

Final Fantasy VII Remake just launched on the Switch 2 and Xbox Series X/S, with Rebirth expected to launch on both systems later this year.

item.title: Nintendo Announces Super Mario Galaxy Movie Direct For This Weekend
item.content:encoded:
It feels like a rare treat for a Nintendo Direct to take us by surprise, now that the events are routinely being pre-empted by leakers. This latest, just revealed by Nintendo to take place on January 25 at 9 a.m. ET (thanks Gematsu), snuck up on me. It‚Äôs a shame it‚Äôs just for the Super Mario Galaxy Movie, rather than meeting our desperate need for Switch 2 game news, but at least it means we‚Äôll get to see Shigeru Miyamoto being all delightfully excited.

Yes, January 25 is a Sunday, which is a weird choice for a Direct. All right-minded games and film journalists are in bed at 9 a.m. on a Sunday morning, so expect some bleary-eyed coverage of the new footage and details being revealed ahead of the movie‚Äôs April 3 release.

Join us on Sunday, Jan 25, at 6am PT for the #NintendoDirect featuring an exclusive look at The Super Mario Galaxy Movie. Please note that no game information will be included in this presentation.

Watch here: https://t.co/gTC114mMLz pic.twitter.com/4DOoFU1fFJ

‚Äî Nintendo of America (@NintendoAmerica) January 23, 2026

Nintendo says this will feature ‚Äúan exclusive look at The Super Mario Galaxy Movie,‚Äù but gives no more information than that. So far we‚Äôve seen a very limited amount of the movie, mostly sticking to a single scene of Mario and Luigi‚Äôs frustrating conversation with a miniature Bowser in his teeny castle. Aside from the reveal of Rosalina, weirdly little has been shown of a movie that‚Äôs due out in just over two months.

The original 2023 Super Mario Bros. Movie may not have been particularly good, but it was wildly successful. Miyamoto even claimed the negative reviews helped the movie succeed. Nintendo and Illumination are presumably feeling very confident of a similar success for the sequel, which will hopefully make better use of the splendid Mario Galaxy setting than first movie did of its Mushroom Kingdom hodgepodge.

Following Sunday‚Äôs Direct, we can expect promotion for the animated movie to really ramp up, although presumably continuing to try to feature Chris Pratt‚Äôs dull-ass voice as little as possible.
